title: Analyzing Issue Scales
code: library(asmcjr) data(franceEES2009) head(franceEES2009) ##      self Extreme Left Communist Socialist Greens UDF (Bayrou) UMP (Sarkozy) ## [1,]   77            0         0         1      5            5             9 ## [2,]   77            0         5         4      5           89             8 ## [3,]   77           89        89        89     89            6            89 ## [4,]    3           89        89        89     89           89            89 ## [5,]   77           77        77        77     77           77            77 ## [6,]    5            0         0         3     89            0            89 ##      National Front Left Party ## [1,]             10          1 ## [2,]             10          4 ## [3,]             10         89 ## [4,]             89         89 ## [5,]             77         77 ## [6,]             89          5 # Running Bayesian Aldrich-Mckelvey scaling on France EES  library(basicspace) ## Loading required package: tools ##  ## ## BASIC SPACE SCALING PACKAGE ## ## 2009 - 2024 ## ## Keith Poole, Howard Rosenthal, Jeffrey Lewis, James Lo, and Royce Carroll ## ## Support provided by the U.S. National Science Foundation ## ## NSF Grant SES-0611974 result.france <- aldmck(franceEES2009, respondent=1, polarity=2,      missing=c(77,88,89), verbose=FALSE) # plot stimuli locations in addition to ideal point density library(ggplot2) plot_resphist(result.france, addStim=TRUE, xlab = "Left-Right") +   theme(legend.position="bottom", aspect.ratio=1) +   guides(shape = guide_legend(override.aes = list(size = 4), nrow=3)) +  labs(shape="Party", colour="Party") ## Warning: The `guide` argument in `scale_*()` cannot be `FALSE`. This was deprecated in ## ggplot2 3.3.4. ## ℹ Please use "none" instead. ## ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the asmcjr package. ##   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/uniofessex/asmcjr/issues>. ## This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. ## Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was ## generated.

what: Example 2: 1968 American National Election Study Urban Unrest and Vietnam War Scales
title: Analyzing Issue Scales
text: ####Running Bayesian Aldrich-Mckelvey
code: data(nes1968_urbanunrest) # Creating object with US president left-right dimensions urban <- as.matrix(nes1968_urbanunrest[,-1]) # Running Bayesian Aldrich-Mckelvey scaling on President positions library(basicspace) result.urb <- aldmck(urban, polarity=2, respondent=5,                      missing=c(8,9), verbose=FALSE) summary(result.urb) ##  ##  ## SUMMARY OF ALDRICH-MCKELVEY OBJECT ## ---------------------------------- ##  ## Number of Stimuli: 4 ## Number of Respondents Scaled: 1191 ## Number of Respondents (Positive Weights): 1110 ## Number of Respondents (Negative Weights): 81 ## Reduction of normalized variance of perceptions: 0.09  ##  ##          Location ## Humphrey   -0.428 ## Johnson    -0.399 ## Nixon       0.015 ## Wallace     0.811

previous_headings: Example 2: 1968 American National Election Study Urban Unrest and Vietnam War Scales
title: Analyzing Issue Scales
code: # recode so that only Humphrey, Nixon and Wallace are present vote <- car:::recode(nes1968_urbanunrest[,1], "3='Humphrey'; 5 = 'Nixon'; 6 = 'Wallace'; else=NA",                      as.factor=FALSE) # Convert vote to factor with appropriate levels vote <- factor(vote, levels=c("Humphrey", "Nixon", "Wallace")) # Plot population distribution by vote choice plot_resphist(result.urb, groupVar=vote, addStim=TRUE,               xlab="Liberal-Conservative")  +   theme(legend.position="bottom", aspect.ratio=1)  +   guides(shape = guide_legend(override.aes =                                 list(size = 4, color=c("gray25", "gray50", "gray75"))),   colour = "none") +   xlim(c(-2,2)) +   labs(shape="Candidate")

title: Bayesian Multidimensional Scaling (BMDS) — BMDS
text: function performs Bayesian Multidimensional Scaling (BMDS) using specified distance matrix predefined positions stimuli. uses JAGS (Just Another Gibbs Sampler) framework estimate positions stimuli lower-dimensional space.

title: Bayesian Multidimensional Scaling (BMDS) — BMDS
code: BMDS(data, posStims, negStims, z, fname = NULL, n.sample = 2500, ...)

title: Bayesian Multidimensional Scaling (BMDS) — BMDS
text: data numeric matrix representing observed distance matrix. matrix symmetric non-negative entries. posStims numeric vector length 2 specifying indices stimuli constrained positive coordinates first second dimensions, respectively. negStims numeric vector length 2 specifying indices stimuli constrained negative coordinates first second dimensions, respectively. z numeric matrix initial positions stimuli. Missing values (NA) indicate positions estimated. fname character string specifying file name JAGS model code written. argument required. n.sample integer specifying number MCMC samples draw. default 2500. ... Additional arguments passed JAGS model, n.chains n.adapt.

title: Bayesian Multidimensional Scaling (BMDS) — BMDS
text: invisible list two components: zhat object containing MCMC samples estimated positions. zhat.ci data frame containing summary statistics (mean, standard deviation, credible intervals) estimated positions.

title: Bayesian Multidimensional Scaling (BMDS) — BMDS
text: function requires rjags package JAGS software run. constructs JAGS model imposes constraints positions certain stimuli (specified posStims negStims) estimates remaining positions using MCMC sampling. model written file specified fname, function runs JAGS model using specified number samples.

title: Bayesian Multidimensional Scaling (BMDS) — BMDS
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load the nations dataset (assuming it's already loaded in your environment) # If not, load or create a similar dataset with distance values. data(nations) # Initialize the z matrix with NA values and set specific starting points z <- matrix(NA, nrow = nrow(nations), ncol = 2) z[10, ] <- 0        # Fix both dimensions of the 10th stimulus to 0 z[11, 2] <- 0       # Fix the second dimension of the 11th stimulus to 0  # Perform Bayesian Multidimensional Scaling (BMDS) nations.bmds <- BMDS(nations,                       posStims = c(7, 2),  # Stimuli to constrain to positive coordinates                      negStims = c(9, 8),  # Stimuli to constrain to negative coordinates                      z = z,               # Initial positions matrix                      fname = "nations_jags.txt",  # File to write the JAGS model                      n.sample = 10000,     # Number of MCMC samples                      n.adapt = 10000)      # Number of adaptation steps  # Inspect the result print(nations.bmds$zhat.ci)  # Print the summary statistics for the estimated positions } # }

title: Double Centering of a Rectangular Matrix — doubleCenterRect
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load the example dataset data("interest1981")  # Prepare the input matrix from columns 9 to 38 input <- as.matrix(interest1981[, 9:38])  # Set a cutoff for the minimum number of non-NA values per row cutoff <- 5 input <- input[rowSums(!is.na(input)) >= cutoff, ]  # Transform the input data input <- (100 - input) / 50  # Square the transformed input values input2 <- input * input  # Replace NA values with the square of the mean of non-NA values input2[is.na(input)] <- (mean(input, na.rm = TRUE))^2  # Perform double centering on the rectangular matrix inputDC <- doubleCenterRect(input2)  # Print the double-centered matrix print(inputDC) } # }

what: Multidimensional Scaling with Missing Data (mlsmu6) — mlsmu6
title: Multidimensional Scaling with Missing Data (mlsmu6) — mlsmu6
text: mlsmu6 function performs multidimensional scaling (MDS) data missing values using iterative approach minimize error sum squares. returns estimated positions stimuli individuals lower-dimensional space.

title: Multidimensional Scaling with Missing Data (mlsmu6) — mlsmu6
code: mlsmu6(input, ndim = 2, cutoff = 5, tol = 5e-04, maxit = 50, id = NULL)

title: Multidimensional Scaling with Missing Data (mlsmu6) — mlsmu6
text: input numeric matrix representing data scaled. Rows correspond individuals, columns correspond stimuli. Missing values (NA) allowed. ndim integer specifying number dimensions estimate. Default 2. cutoff integer specifying minimum number non-missing values required row included analysis. Default 5. tol numeric value specifying convergence tolerance iterative procedure. Default 0.0005. maxit integer specifying maximum number iterations allowed. Default 50. id optional vector identifiers rows (individuals) input matrix. provided, added output.

title: Multidimensional Scaling with Missing Data (mlsmu6) — mlsmu6
text: list class mlsmu6 containing: inds data frame estimated positions individuals lower-dimensional space. stims data frame estimated positions stimuli lower-dimensional space. iter matrix tracking error sum squares iterations.

title: Multidimensional Scaling with Missing Data (mlsmu6) — mlsmu6
text: function starts centering input data, applies singular value decomposition (SVD) initialize positions stimuli individuals. iteratively adjusts positions minimize error sum squares. process stops change error sum squares falls specified tolerance (tol) maximum number iterations (maxit) reached.

title: Multidimensional Scaling with Missing Data (mlsmu6) — mlsmu6
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load the interest1981 dataset and prepare the input matrix data(interest1981) input <- as.matrix(interest1981[, 9:38]) cutoff <- 5 input <- input[rowSums(!is.na(input)) >= cutoff, ] input <- (100 - input) / 50 input2 <- input * input input2[is.na(input)] <- (mean(input, na.rm = TRUE))^2 inputDC <- doubleCenterRect(input2)  # Perform SVD and initialize positions xsvd <- svd(inputDC) ndim <- 2 stims <- xsvd$v[, 1:ndim] inds <- xsvd$u[, 1:ndim] for (i in 1:ndim) {   stims[, i] <- stims[, i] * sqrt(xsvd$d[i])   inds[, i] <- inds[, i] * sqrt(xsvd$d[i]) }  # Run mlsmu6 to get the MDS solution out <- mlsmu6(input = interest1981[, 9:38], ndim = 2, cutoff = 5,               id = factor(interest1981$party, labels = c("D", "R")))  # Inspect the results print(out$inds) print(out$stims) plot(out$iter, type = "b", main = "Error Sum of Squares Over Iterations") } # }

title: Plot Blackbox Results with Optional Grouping and Issue Vectors — plot_blackbox
text: result list object containing results blackbox analysis. object include individual-level data dimension. dims numeric vector length 2 indicating dimensions plot. whichRes optional integer specifying result set use result$individuals list. NULL, highest dimension used. groupVar optional vector grouping data points. NULL, grouping applied. issueVector vector indicating issues include vectors plot. can character vector column names numeric vector column indices. data data frame containing original data used analysis. Required issueVector specified. missing vector values treated missing data. rug Logical, TRUE, adds marginal rugs plot. xlab character string x-axis label. NULL, label generated automatically. main character string plot title. NULL, title added. ylab character string y-axis label. NULL, label generated automatically. nudgeX numeric vector nudging x positions issue vector labels. Defaults NULL. nudgeY numeric vector nudging y positions issue vector labels. Defaults NULL. ... code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # CDS2000 is a dataset containing U.S. Congressional data, # where the first column represents party affiliation: 1 for Democrats, 2 for Republicans.  # Recode the party variable: 1 = 'Democrat', 2 = 'Republican', others as NA party <- car::recode(CDS2000[,1],                      "1='Democrat'; 2='Republican'; else=NA",                      as.factor=TRUE)  # Create a Blackbox plot to compare the distribution of different parties in a two-dimensional space plot_blackbox(result.repdem, dims=c(1, 2), groupVar=party,               xlab="First Dimension\n(Left-Right)",               ylab="Second Dimension") +   theme(legend.position="bottom", aspect.ratio=1) +   guides(shape=guide_legend(override.aes=list(size=4))) +   labs(colour="Party") } # }

text: data frame following 16 variables: cong Congress number. id Unique identifier member Congress. state State abbreviation member's state. dist District number House members, 0 Senators. lstate Full name member's state. party Political party affiliation (e.g., Democrat, Republican). name Name member Congress. dwnom1 first dimension DW-NOMINATE score, typically representing liberal-conservative spectrum. dwnom2 second dimension DW-NOMINATE score, often representing regional secondary factors. dwnom1bse Standard error first dimension DW-NOMINATE score. dwnom2bse Standard error second dimension DW-NOMINATE score. corrbse Correlation first second dimension standard errors. LogL Log-likelihood legislator's votes DW-NOMINATE model. nchoice Number roll-call votes legislator participated . nerror Number classification errors (votes incorrectly predicted model). gmp Geometric mean probability, measure fit DW-NOMINATE model.
